EN_Text: Do we know each other? If not, I´m Freddie.In our workshop as of now I will also have to deal with ECAS. Therefore I have to check what´s going on.
What you should know at the end of this module ...
What the terms ECAS and ELM mean
The advantages of an electronic air suspension system
The primary physical principles of ECAS
How the electronic control of ECAS works
What is meant with ECAS diagnosis
Why calibration and parameterizing of an ECAS system are necessary and how they are performed
Example:ECAS control unit for motor vehicle 4x2446 055 301 0
Enhancement of suspension: cargo, vehicle and road surface are protected
Always the same spring travel due to the constant driving level
Improvement of steering and braking capabilities
Adjustment of the load platform to the ramp height
Keeps the vehicle height constant at desired level
Raising and lowering of lifting axles
Faster and more exact raising and lowering
The electronic control provides faster and more exact raising and lowering.
Only using an electronic air suspension system it´s possible to adjust the load platform to the ramp height.
ECAS reduces the air consumption when driving.
ECAS provides the additional functions of self-monitoring and diagnosis.
Only using an electronic air suspension system it´s possible to retain the driving level and thus the spring travel.
Mark all correct statements regarding the advantages of the electronic air suspension system ECAS compared to conventional air suspension systems.
That´s true. The control unit is able to achieve a desired height faster and more exact as it is possible via manual control.
That´s wrong. Even using a conventional air suspension system the platform can be adjusted to the ramp height. However, it´s not performed automatically.
That´s true. ECAS consumes less air, because the control unit recognizes whether the vehicle is in motion, and the driving level is readjusted no more than necessary.
That´s right. During operation the control unit is able to detect error conditions, to react immediately and to store them internally for subsequent diagnosis.
This statement is not correct, because also a conventional air suspension system is able to perform this. However, not so exact as ECAS can.
That´s true. ECAS reacts at the push on a button. For instance a specific height stored in the control unit is automatically addressed, without annoying manual readjustment.
That´s right, you marked all appropriate statements.
And what about different levels of the platform? I guess it also coheres somehow with pressure, or am I wrong?
The pressure is higher than before.
The pressure is lower than before.
Whether higher or lower depends on the design of the bellow.
Please mark the correct statement. After that click on
A load platform is raised by pressurizing the air suspension bellows, after that the air supply is closed. What´s the pressure in each bellow when raising is finished?
Unfortunately this is wrong. Please consider the only variable the pressure depends on.
Because the load remains unchanged, after raising the bellows pressure is the same.
No, it is not influenced by design of the bellow.
You are right. Because the load remains unchanged, the bellows pressure is the same after raising.
When the platform has been loaded the bellows pressure is the same as before.
When the platform has been loaded the bellows pressure is increased.
After unloading the bellows pressure is decreased.
After unloading the bellows pressure is the same as before unloading.
That´s wrong. Because the load applies more force to the bellows, the bellows pressure cannot be the same.

This statement is true. The following formula is applied: pressure is force per unit area. Because the bellow´s cross section area remains the same and the applied weight force is increased, the pressure is raised.

This statement is true. The following formula is applied: pressure is force per unit area. Because the bellow´s cross section area remains the same and the applied weight force is decreased, the pressure is lowered.
That´s wrong. Because after unloading the applied weight force is decreased, the bellows pressure cannot be the same.
Exactly, the bellows pressure is increased and decreased depending on the loading condition.
How operates the electronic control of ECAS?
Please drag the labels below on the blue areas of the picture. After that click on
Using the ECAS remote-control unit for instance you can prescribe a new reference level.
The ECAS electronics compares the actual level to the current reference level and performs a readjustment, if needed.
The height sensor detects the actual level and transmits this value as electrical signal to the ECU.
During control processes the solenoid valve increases or decreases the air pressure in the air suspension below according to the signals of the ECAS ECU.
During a control process the air suspension bellow raises and lowers the superstructure.
That´s correct. You assigned all labels correctly.
During an ECAS control process a so called "overshooting" is used to reach the reference level in any case.
By pulsing the ECAS solenoid valve an overshooting is prevented.
The ECAS solenoid valve is pulsed, when after overshooting the actual level has to be readjusted to the reference level.
On the left you see an ECAS control process.Please mark the correct statement:
This statement is wrong. Overshooting is not wanted, for the very reason that the time is lost needed for readjusting in opposite direction.
Overshooting is prevented before reaching the reference level by pulsing the solenoid valve.
This statement is wrong. In this case a reversed control of the solenoid valve would be required.
Right. By pulsing the solenoid valve before reaching the reference level overshooting is prevented.
Static wheel load changesduring loading and unloading
ECAS quickly readjusts any deviation from the reference level.
Dynamic wheel load changescaused e.g. by bumpy roads
ECAS blocks the air suspension bellows and thus saves compressed air.Readjustment only at longer intervals e.g. to compensate pressure loss
That´s a smart feature of ECAS, because a lot of compressed air is saved when driving.But that´s only possible, because the system is able to detect whether the vehicle is in motion.
Move the mouse pointer over the red underlayed terms to get to know more about it.

The vehicle manufacturer or a subsequent user is able to modify and permanently store certain values in the ECAS ECU using the diagnostic software. These values are named parameters, and changing them is called parameterizing.Thus the ECAS system is attuned to the vehicle.For instance it has to be declared using parameterizing whether a lifting axle is present and has to be controlled by ECAS, or not.

ECAS uses height sensors to detect the current level. Even when having the same vehicle and sensor type and the same level they provide different values, for instance because their mounting position is a little bit different.Therefore each sensor has to be calibrated. This means: a certain level, e.g. the reference level during driving ("driving level") is exactly addressed, and the precise value measured by the sensor at this level is stored into the ECU.That way the ECU is able to exactly address this level later on.
For PC diagnosis a commercially available PC is sufficient.
More about purchase of the ECAS Diagnostic Software you will get to know in module 3 of this course.
WABCO Diagnostic Interface Set (serial): with connecting cable for COM interfaceOrder no. 446 301 021 0
WABCO Diagnostic Interface Set (USB): with connecting cable for USB interface and driver softwareOrder no. 446 301 022 0
Hardware requirements of the diagnostic software:
ca. 30 MB free hard disk memory
Color display 1024x768 pixels at the minimum
a free COM interface (9 pins) resp. USB connection
Operating system Windows 9x or Windows NT 4.0 / 2000 / XP or compatible successors
WABCO holds approved vehicle configurations available,as attuned parameter sets and appropriate circuit diagrams.
Individual variants adjusted by the manufacturer are possible
on the weatherproofed foil e.g. the WABCO special foil order no. 899 200 922 4
At last I get to know, what the practical use of this label is, and why a lot of parameters are noted here.
1 byte (= 8 bit) is able to store a value between 0 and 255:
for instance a vehicle speed, expressed directly in km/h: a byte value of 60 corresponds to 60 km/h
or a proportionally transformed pressure value, whereas one unit corresponds to 1/16 bar: in this case a byte value of 60 corresponds to 3,75 bar.
1 height sensor on the rear axle corresponds to bit value 1
2 height sensors on the rear axle correspond to bit value 0
Option parameters combine up to 8 single values in one byte value.
An option parameter combines up to 8 separate single values ("options") in one byte value.
A value parameter stores a single physical value, transformed into a byte value.
An option parameter collects multiple value parameters.
Some value parameters can store only one bit, some an entire byte.
This statement ist true. Each of the 8 bits of an option parameter contains one bit value with its own meaning.Because some bits of an option parameter may not be used, it´s correct to say "up to".
This statement is true: the intire byte value corresponds to a single physical value.
This statement is wrong. An option parameter collects multiple bit values. In contrast, each value parameter stores one byte value.
That´s wrong. Value parameters always store byte values.
That´s right, you understood the meaning of both terms.
It´s hard to believe that it is possible to generate 256 different states using only 8 lamps.I would like to try out this, before I am convinced ...
Change the byte value to 22 by switching the bits on or off. Try to get by with 2 mouse clicks.
Solution: To increase the byte value from 21 to 22, bit 0 with value 1 is switched off and bit 1 with value 2 is switched on. (The bits 2 and 4 remain switched on).
Height sensor 441 050 123 0 with linkage to measure the actual level
The ECAS ECU converts each sensor signal to a count value, which means to a byte value between 4 and 255 counts.
Height sensor 441 050 123 0 with linkage to measure the actual level
The ECAS ECU converts each sensor signal to a count value, which means to a byte value betwwen 4 and 255 counts.
Newer ECAS ECUs:16-bit processingbetween 256 and 65535 timer ticks
Up to now:8-bit processingbetween 4 and 255 counts
The terms "counts" and "timer ticks" mean the same. They are digital units in the range from 4 to 255.
ECAS ECUs with 8-bit processing convert the input signals of the height sensors to so called counts.
ECAS ECUs with 16-bit processing convert the input signals of the height sensors to so called timer-ticks.
Whether the ECU uses counts or timer ticks depends on the signal of the connected height sensor.
Depending on the ECAS ECU, the signals of the height sensors are converted to counts or timer ticks.
This statement is wrong. In contrast to counts which are 8-bit values, timer ticks are 16-bit values in the range from 255 to 65.535. Timer ticks are used starting with newer 16-bit ECAS ECUs.
This statement is correct, indications in counts are 8-bit values.
This statement is correct, indications in timer ticks are 16-bit values.
That´s wrong. Conversion to counts or timer ticks is done by the ECU, depending on the actual ECU variant.
Right, you understood the meaning of the terms "counts" and "timer ticks".
Calibration of the height sensors means
to address the driving level and store the resulting value in the ECU (in counts).
to achieve and to store the upper and the lower level.
after replacement of a height sensor.
At first the driving level specified by the vehicle manufacturer is achieved using the diagnostic software.The resulting count value is stored as driving level in the ECU.
In the same way the upper and the lower level are stored as count values in the ECU.
OK, I have to achieve the driving level specified by the manufacturer.Great! But how is it, that I know the exact height I have to address?
Gauge specified by the vehicle manufacturer to extend the air suspension bellow to a predefined height
A spacer tube or block designated by the vehicle manufacturer is placed on the axle and the vehicle frame is lowered onto it.
The marks on the shock absorber indicate the position of the outer tube at driving level.
Top edge of the side member
Bottom edge of the side member
When specifiing levels in millimeters the used reference dimension type has to be indicated.
Addressing a prescribed driving level using a specification in millimeters for reference dimension A.

Using some reference dimensions the current load conditions affect the results due to tyre deflection. Thererfore these reference dimensions should be avoided.Please mark all reference dimensions where the load conditions have no effect.
Top edge of the vehicle frame
Bottom edge of the vehicle frame
When using the reference dimension A, which is the distance between the bottom edge of the vehicle frame and the middle of the axle beam, the tyre deflection affects not the measured value.
When using the reference dimension B, which is the distance between the bottom edge of the vehicle frame and the top of the axle beam, the tyre deflection affects not the measured value.
When using the reference dimension C, which is the distance between the top edge of the vehicle frame and the middle of the axle beam, the tyre deflection affects not the measured value.
When using the reference dimension D, which is the distance between the top edge of the vehicle frame and the top of the axle beam, the tyre deflection affects not the measured value.

When using the reference dimension E, the current load affects the measured value, because the distance between the top edge of the vehicle frame and the road surface is influenced by the tyre deflection.

When using the reference dimension F, the current load affects the measured value, because the distance between the bottom edge of the vehicle frame and the road surface is influenced by the tyre deflection.
Right, you recognized the related reference dimensions correctly.
When the calibrated count values break certain rules, after calibration an error message occurs.The rules are as follows ...
count value of the upper level >
count value driving level + triple reference level tolerance + 3 counts
count value driving level - double reference level tolerance
Lower level: 21 counts; Driving level: 100 counts; Upper level: 116 counts
Lower level: 15 counts; Driving level: 91 counts; Upper level: 132 counts
Lower level: 31 counts; Driving level: 96 counts; Upper level: 253 counts
Mark the case where a calibration error is generated.After that click on
In the following the reference level tolerance amounts to 5 counts. Which case generates a calibration error?
count value of the upper level >
count value driving level + triple reference level tolerance + 3 counts
count value driving level - double reference level tolerance

In the first case the second rule is broken. The distance between driving and upper level is too small. Driving level 100 counts + 3 x 5 + 3 results in 118 counts. The upper level should amount to at least 119  counts.
No, this generates not a calibration error, because these count values comply with all three rules.
Right, the second rule is broken here. The distance between driving and upper level is too small.
Pressure sensor for measuring the bellows pressure
Lowering of the lifting axle when reaching a certain bellows pressure
To calibrate the pressure sensor the bellows are vented ....
... and the resulting count value is stored in the ECU as 0 bar.
ELM stands for Electronic Leveling Module
Operation mostly using the fixed mounted control box
Remote-control unit for storing and addressing ramp levels
Simplified and compact variant of an electronic air suspension system
Readjusting to a reference level during loading and unloading
Storing and addressing of 2 different ramp levels
Commissioning using the control box or the remote-control unit
How to commission ELM using the remote-control unit, you will get to know here ...
TCE stands for Trailer Central Electronic
TCE provides and integrates numerous functions.
Even the functions of the ECAS ECU are already integrated.
The further ECAS components are directly connected to TCE.
That´s new to me.Thus WABCO provides three different electronic air suspension systems.However, because TCE integrates the original ECAS functions, finally we have two: ECAS and ELM.
